case_vignette: A 28-year-old man who works as a resident in general surgery presents feeling "burned out" for the last 2 months. He says he has been working extremely long hours under stressful conditions, which makes him irritable, edgy, unfocused, and forgetful. He says he also has severe anxiety about how these symptoms are affecting his performance at work, making it difficult for him to sleep even when he has time off. The patient is referred for counseling and is prescribed some mild sleep aids. At follow-up a few months later, he says he is feeling much improved due to improved staffing at the hospital and a more manageable workload.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

I see. It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of burnout. Burnout is a state of emotional, mental, and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress. It can lead to feelings of hopelessness, detachment, and cynicism towards work and life in general.

Great, it sounds like you've made some progress in addressing the work-related stress that was contributing to your burnout. Improved staffing and a more manageable workload can definitely make a big difference in how you feel.

Can you tell me more about your current symptoms? Are you still experiencing anxiety, irritability, and forgetfulness, or have these symptoms improved as well?
My symptoms have improved; I'm feeling much better now.

Great to hear that your symptoms have improved! It's important to take care of yourself and prioritize your well-being, especially when you're working in a high-stress environment.

Can you tell me more about what you've been doing to take care of yourself? Have you made any changes to your work routine or schedule, or have you found any new coping mechanisms or stress-reduction strategies?
